  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-44935].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Customer reported that, in Confluence pages, links are distinguished by color only. 

Confluence Cloud version does not allow CSS Customization. You are able to change links color (look and feel configuration settings), however, it changes All links within Confluence application, this is only regarding the ones on pages text. 

There is also a best practice, for accessibility, from w3 on how to display links described here: [https://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG20-TECHS/F73.html]

h3. Suggested Solution
It would be better if we add something like underlining or shading, into the style that links are displayed, even better if we make an option to change default link styles (for pages only)

h3. Workaround 
The only suitable workaround for this would be to manually format links in a way that differs it from the text.
fields.summary: Distinguish Links from text

h3. Problem Definition

It is not always clear to users how to edit a file in the Office Connector interface when previewing a file from a Confluence page. In order to edit the file, you must click on {{...}} at the top right corner of the page, and then select *Edit in office*. An example of the user experience for editing from the previewer is shown in the screenshot below: 

!edit_options.png|thumbnail!

As you can see, the user must first click {{...}} and then the option for "Edit in office" appears. 

In contrast, when viewing the file from the attachments list, there are buttons that clearly direct the user to edit the file. The options should be similar. 
h3. Suggested Solution

Add an “Edit file” icon directly visible in the file previewer, instead of having it under the {{...}} option. This will make it more clear to users that they can edit the file in Confluence.

h4. Summary
Let's say our hierarchy of pages in a page are as such:
 * Parent A (contains ImageA.png and ImageB.png)
 ** Child A (displays ImageA.png that was attached in Parent A)
 ** Child B (displays ImageB.png that was attached in Parent A)

On pages Child A and Child B, the only way to know that ImageA.png and ImageB.png originated from Parent A is to edit the page and hover over the image. At that point, you'd be able to view which space and page the image came from. A sample is shown below:

 !Attachment hover.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Suggestion
The method mentioned above is very troublesome and difficult for users to identify which page actually has the attachment attached to it. Perhaps Confluence can do one of the following:
 * Automatically link the attachment so clicking on it will immediately redirect users to the original page where the attachment was attached to.
 * Provide a macro which can list out the links to pages whose attachments are displayed on the current page.

Any other implementation method that will allow an easier way of knowing which page provides the attachment would be great.

h4. Workaround
This will achieve suggestion #1 above, but has to be manually done.
 # Edit an existing page or create a new page.
 # Insert an attachment from another page into the page from step #1 above.
 # Click on the newly added attachment on the page editor.
 # Click on "Link".
 # Search for the page where the attachment came from.
 # Select the page.
 # Click on "Insert".
 # Save the page.
 # Click on the attachment to test the URL/page redirection.

Das OpenOLAT 10.5 Benutzerhandbuch hat zahlreiche Kommafehler. Insbesondere nach Relativpronomen (meistens DIE) wird oft keine Komma gesetzt. Grammatikalische Fehler sind in der Regel selten, aber in folgendem Abschnitt sehr häufig (inkl. Kommafehler):

Mit dem Coaching-Tool haben Gruppen- und Kursbetreuer die Möglichkeit, alle Ihnen zugewiesen Benutzer auf einen Blick zu sehen und zu verwalten. Falls Sie eine Gruppe oder einen Kurs betreuen, [KEIN KOMMA] und im Kurs wird durch Bewertungsdaten ein Leistungsnachweis ausgelöst, so wird der Reiter "Coaching" in der oberen Navigation erscheinen. Das Coaching-Werkzeug bietet einen Kursübergreifenden [ADJEKTIV: KLEINSCHREIBUNG] Überblick über den Bewertungsstatus von Lernenden - den betreuten Benutzern.  Kursbesitzer erhalten Zugriff auf die Daten aller ihrem Kurs eingebundenen Benutzer, egal ob als Kurs- oder Gruppenmitglied. Dabei werden alle bewertbaren Kursbausteine berücksichtigt. Bitte beachten Sie, dass Kurse erst dann als bestanden angezeigt werden können, wenn der Kurshauptknoten ebenfalls entsprechend konfiguriert wurde. Zugriff auf betreute Personen gibt es auf drei verschiedene Weisen.

Benutzen Sie das Menü [KOMMA fehlt] um die Lernstatistiken von einzelnen Benutzern, Gruppen oder ganzen Kursen zu sehen. Ein Fortschrittsbalken zeigt an [KOMMA] wie weit ein Benutzer, eine Gruppe oder ein Kurs bereits benötigte Bewertungen erhalten haben. Die Listenansicht kann nach Spalten sortiert werden.

Beim Einstieg in das Coaching-Werkzeug finden Sie alle von Ihnen betreuten OpenOLAT-Benutzer. Diese Tabelle verschafft Ihnen einen Überblick, in wievielen [WIE VIELEN] von Ihnen betreuten Kursen ein Benutzer Mitglied ist, [KEIN KOMMA] und wieviele [WIE VIELEN]  er davon schon bestanden hat. Ein Klick auf den Namen öffnet die Benutzerspezifische [ADJEKTIV: KLEINSCHREIBUNG] Kursübersicht. h3. Problem Definition
While using Share button it's not possible to search for users which are in Confluence user directory (internal or external) if they are not assigned to the group with "can use permissions" or do not have "can use" permissions assigned individually.

Such approach is helping to improve user search performance *but* the user can lack this functionality when it's required to share the page in the space with Anonimous access.

h4. Business case
Example business case configuration:
* Confluence and JIRA Service Desk. 
* JIRA is used for user management in Confluence
* JIRA SD customers are synchronized but their group doesn't have "can use" permission (in order to reduce user count)
* JIRA SD is set up for [Serving customers with a knowledge base|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/SERVICEDESKSERVER031/Serving+customers+with+a+knowledge+base]

The following case has happen:
# Big number of customers from the same department created support ticket related to the same issue.
# The support agent decided to write a new KB and share with the customers from that department.

*Expected behavior*
The support engineer can use the embed search in Share dialog to identify the group or user who is in the directory but without "can use" permissions.
*Actual behavior*
The support engineer is getting an empty search result for groups and users without "can use" permissions.

h3. Suggested Solution
Two possible solutions available:
# Include all users and groups from the directory to Share button search (irrelative to "can use" permission)
# Make an option to manually include selected groups without "can use" permission from the directory 
 
h3. Workaround 
Currently no workaround available, just to give the users can use permission.
fields.summary: Ability to Share pages with users and groups without "can use" permissions
